title: Reputation-Aware Federated Learning Client Selection based on Stochastic Integer Programming (SCS)
summaries: propose __a client selection algorithm__ when the reputations of clients are not fully reliable, achieving [1] most advantageous performance-cost trade-off, compared to [1] FedAvg [2] FedAvg50 [3] NRACS [4] RRAFL

in the proposed 2-stage client selection algorithm, the clients are divided into 3 groups based on reputation values, aiming to (1) minimize hiring costs for all servers and avoid herding in the first stage, and (2) maintain the performance in the global model in the second stage
systemModel: a set $\mathcal{M}=\{1, ..., M\}$ of master nodes (servers), a set $\mathcal{N}=\{1, ..., N\}$ of worker nodes (clients)

each worker node has a reputation value $Q_n \in [0,1]$ and based on $Q_n$ the worker set $\mathcal{N}$ is divided into $3$ sub-groups: 1) $i \in \mathcal{N}_{hi}$, 2) $j \in \mathcal{N}_{mi}$, 3) $k \in \mathcal{N}_{lo}$
the problem is formulated as a stochastic integer programming (SIP) problem [see <u>1. Problem Formulation</u>]
stage I (deployment stage) 3): model aggregation and adversarial behaviors detection
stage II (recourse stage) 1): hire high reputation workers only
stage II 2)-4) continues after stage I for $\theta_S$ rounds to recover the performance in global model
motivation: There is an uptrend in research [8], [9], [10], of using reputation values to hire worker nodes.
However, reputation value only indirectly measures the quality and trustworthiness of the worker nodes.
For an instance, one worker labelled with relatively higher reputation may still unintentionally misbehave.
Such indirect approach introduces uncertainty to the accuracy of behaviour the worker node might reflect in practice.
Over reliance on the same pool of high reputation workers could be detrimental as well
It could lead to the problem of herding.
questions: select clients for improving model accuracy and considering potential misbehavior and the cost of hiring
techniques: $\begin{array}{ll}  \underset{x_{i,m}^1,y_{j,m}^1,z_{k,m}^1,\beta_i^2(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_m))}{\operatorname{min}} & \sum\limits_{m=\mathcal{M}} \left(\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{hi}}(C_{hi,m}x_{i,m}^1)+\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{mi}}(C_{mi,m}y_{j,m}^1)+\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{lo}}(C_{lo,m}z_{k,m}^1)\right)+\mathbb{E}\left[W(C_{mi,m}y^1_{j,m}(\mathcal{S}_m),C_{lo,m}z^1_{k,m}(\mathcal{S}_m))\right] \\& \sum\limits_{m=\mathcal{M}} \left(\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{hi}}x_{i,m}^1+\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{mi}}y_{j,m}^1+\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{lo}}z_{k,m}^1\right)\leq m_{cap} \\& \sum\limits_{m=\mathcal{M}} \left(\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{hi}}x_{i,m}^1\right)\geq \sum\limits_{m=\mathcal{M}} \left(\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{mi}}y_{j,m}^1+\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{lo}}z_{k,m}^1\right)\\& \bar{x}_{i,m}\leq d_i \\& \bar{y}_{j,m}\leq d_j \\& \bar{z}_{k,m}\leq d_k \\& \bar{x}_{i,m}\leq \varphi x_{i,m}^1 \\& \bar{y}_{j,m}\leq \varphi y_{j,m}^1 \\& \bar{z}_{k,m}\leq \varphi z_{k,m}^1 \\& \bar{\beta_i}(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_m)) \leq d_i \\& \bar{\beta_i}(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_m)) \leq \varphi \beta_i^2(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_m)) \\& \sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{hi}}\bar{x}_{i,m}+\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{mi}}\bar{y}_{j,m}+\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{lo}}\bar{z}_{k,m} \geq \varphi(\lambda) \\& \sum\limits_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\sum\limits_{\mathcal{S}_m\in\mathbb{S}}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{hi}} \beta_i^2(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_m))+\sum\limits_{m \in\mathcal{M}}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{hi}}x^1_{i,m}\leq m_{cap} \\& \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_m)\left(\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{hi}}\bar{x}_{i,m}+\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{mi}}\bar{y}_{j,m}+\sum\limits_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{lo}}\bar{z}_{k,m}\right) + \sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{hi}}\bar{\beta}_i(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_m)) \geq \varphi(\lambda)\end{array}$
